[Header]

Brenham Texas.
April 15th 1881.

[Body]

My dear Professor
Your good letter came to hand
by due course of mail & read with much interest
I have seen Lewis & Peeler's battle no. 2 –
I think Lewis is "left" in no 2. as he was in no 1.
His fling at Gov G. to say the least of it, is
in bad taste & infelicitous. When I attack
a man it must be the living – not the dead –
In his attack on the living I think he refers
to Capt R. & Prof. C. I had planned to defeat
[crossed-out: &] Peeler in this district – but the Gov was
victorious in his plan for a new Board –
Had the Legislature elected a new Board
C.C Garrett would have been your member
from this district – Who is C.C. Higgins
of your new Board? He is a new man to me –
Thanks for kind expressions for me, in our
present embarrassment here – Our trouble
threatens to be serious – Some of our good
but money loving citizens claim to have
found illegality in our School & R R tax –

[Header]

[1881, April 15]

An injunction restraining the City Collector
has been temporarily granted – The City
Atty has filed an answer – asking that
the injunction be dissolved. No matter
what may be the result in the District Court
it will go to the Supreme Court for final
adjudication – Few men live long enough
to realize the decision of a Texas Supreme Court.
The next day after the suspension we obtained
the use of the School buildings for the present &
opened School with 130 pay students –
I shall seek employment elsewhere at
an early day – I may not find –
We have a corps of excellent teachers – native
and to "the manor born" – I like them all
& am unwilling to enter into a scramble
for patronage – What do you think when Prof.
H. saw the law for the reorganization of your
Board he moved "heaven & earth" to influence
the Gov to send his name to the Senate
for appointment – Irrepressible is not
the word I want but my vocabulary is
too meager – "My friend Tom Scott" is down

[Header] [1881, April 15]

will he do now - Play Court
at whose throne? Maj B is still at
Waxahachie - We had "cards" to Miss
Julien's marriage a few weeks ago -

By the by, I learn Dr. M has sold his "Sabine
farm" hard by the A.M.C. Where is the old
man? At his age & with a young family
the old man has my poor sympathy -
I have no unkind word for him -

"Jimmie & Ball"! I wonder if they survive?
I see tone of our State press is beginning
to "pepper" the University - Galveston N.
gives it the cold shoulder - I am not
comfortable over the attitude of affairs
here - but fret & chafe as little as possible -

I think 90 o/o of our people endorse our
schools & my administration of them -
But the "grist" is in the mill & who will
be able to stand - Any changes contemplated
in Bryan? Our weather for a few days
has been phenomenal - All well -

Your good letters cheer me always -

Your friend
J. T. Hand
